{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3021622,"name":"Mr.R^2","username":"Mr.R_2","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mr.r_2/{size}/89723_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-12T16:10:53.125Z","cooked":"

I am not sure if this is in the correct forum, or even if it is worth posting in general, but this morning, when I logged into my personal computer, I got a seemingly unavoidable message forcing me to either upgrade to Windows 11 now, or decline the upgrade.

While it did not explicitly say this was a one-time offer, it implied this pretty strongly.

I did a bit of research, and it seems this is definitely not the case.

Nerds Chalk – 7 Jan 22

If I Decline Windows 11 Upgrade, Can I Get It Later? [Explained]

While most Windows users are busy upgrading their PCs with Windows 11, many don’t want to let go of Windows 10. At least not yet. Besides, Microsoft will officially end Windows 10 support in …

https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/all/declined-windows-11-upgrade-will-i-be-asked-again/bb43b499-aecd-42a5-ba19-676f4f0cb628

So, I thought I would post this as I would have been a bit concerned had it happened to any of our team machines running Windows 10 Home. I just wanted to spare anyone a few minutes of potential panic/ confusion during build season.
